COMMEMORATED AT McCOY HALL
School of Hygiene and Public Health Formally Opened—Dr.
George E. Vincent, President of the Rockefeller Foundation,
Delivers Memorable Address—President Goodnow
Absent on Account of Illness.
The celebration of the forty-third anniversary of the University
on February 22 at McCoy Hall was of two fold significance. In addition to the observance of the date of the birth of the institution, the
occasion marked the formal opening of the new School of Hygiene and
Public Health.
Unfortunately, President Goodnow was unable to preside over
the exercises, on account of a temporary indisposition, and Dr. William
H. Welch was requested to take his place. As Dr. Welch had been especially interested in the School of Hygiene and Public Health it was
very fitting that he should be able to introduce, as the orator of the
day, Dr. George E. Vincent, president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
It will be remembered that large contributions were made by this
famous institution for the founding of the new department of the
Medical School.
Dr. Welch and Dr. Vincent headed the academic procession, which
came slowly into the hall at 11 o'clock. Following them were the
trustees, the faculty in caps and gowns, the alumni, headed by Dr.
G. L. Radcliffe, the students of the Graduate and Medical Departments, and, finally, the undergraduate body, led by Dr. Abercrombie.
After the invocation by Rev. Edward H. Griffin, former dean of
the University faculty, Dr. Welch introduced Dr. Vincent, who delivered a highly interesting address, appropriate to the opening of the
School of Hygiene and Public Health.
His address was followed by the presentation of a portrait of Professor John J. Abel, after a brief sketch of his valuable research work
by Mr. Griffith B. Coale. The gift was accepted by Dr. Welch, who
then read the address of Dr. Goodnow. He took occasion to mention
the fact that Secretary of War Newton D. Baker, who was recently
elected to the Board of Trustees, was among the assembled dignitaries.
The President's announcements
included a short account of the
academic responsibilities thrown
on American universities as a result of the war. "The present is

CAPTAIN KING TELLS OF RAID
Gives Detailed Account of Attack on
the Huns in which He was
Wounded.

Capt. W. H. King, D. S. 0., of
the Canadian Army, spoke at the
Thursday Open Forum, giving a
vivid account of a raid in which
he took part in the latter part of
1917, at Hill No. 70, near Lens.
He illustrated with a diagram of
the trenches raided, the three
parts being called Nun's Alley, Nabob Alley and Cinnabar. After
rehearsing the raid behind the
lines in trenches marked out with
tape, the three companies came
up to the attacking trench at 10.30
in the evening, making ready to attack at 12.30.
The night was clear, with a
full moon. The party advanced,
crawling through the barbed wire
entanglements and falling into
shell holes half filled with water.
The Germans kept the skies lit up
with flare shells. The barrage of
the artillery in the rear sometimes fell short. The companies
searched some houses in a village
and found them empty, erected
barricades in the enemy trenches,
and worked back and forth in the
latter, bombing out dug-outs and
taking prisoners and machine
guns.
At 1 o'clock the signal was
given to return, all except supporting machine gun parties to
cover the retirement. After ten
minutes these also returned. Besides the destruction of the enemy trenches, capturing of prisoners and machine guns, the raid resulted in the acquirement of a lot
of valuable information, a great
increase in the morale of the Canadian troops and a corresponding
lowering of that of the boche.
In was in this engagement that
Captain King was slightly wounded. In his lecture he described the
treatment in the first-aid posts,
dressing stations, casualty clearing stations and the base hospitals.

- The army intelligence test has
been given to the Freshmen of the
University under the personal direction of Dr. Knight Dunlap. One
set of the compiled results will be
sent to the department at Washington, the other set will be kept
at Hopkins for comparison with
the examination results of the
same students. From this comparison, it is hoped that some information may be gained as to the
real value of the formal examination in its relation to the intelligence of the individual.
There are eights tests in all,
each with a time limit. The first
depends upon the accurate and
careful interpretation of the instructors' directions; the second is
a series of simple mathematical
problems; the third, a test of common sense, which requires the
checking of the probable answer
out of three written after the
question; the fourth deals with the
power of discernment between
meaning of words in pairs; the
fifth requires the restating of
twenty-four short, mixed-up questions, and the correct answers;
the problem of the sixth is the
completion of the sequence of
twenty arrangements of numbers;
test seven concerns the relating of
words so as to correspond with a
given example; the last test is
for general knowledge about the .
location of well known cities,
characteristics of certain jewels,
and occupations of famous men.
The results of these tests as applied in the army have been 'satisfactory. Dr. Dunlap, with a commission of major, was on the psychological examining board at one
of the northern aviation camps,
and for the purpose of gaining statistics of some value, intends to
continue the tests for the next few
years.

previous year. It is true that the
traditional, solemn, impressive
note predominated; but, in place
of time grim, oppressive war clouds,
which hovered so ominously over
the 1918 exercises, the clear atmosphere of victory, peace and
hope pervaded this celebration.

a chaplain in the Marine Corps—

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in publishing the following letter
from Lieut. Walter S. Hastings,
former instructor in French at
the University. He is now with
the American Legation at Berne,
holding the office of assistant to
the Olitary attache.
Lausanne, Switzerland,
January 12.
My Dear Dr. Brush—I have
been in Switzerland for over a
month now, and after reporting to
Berne for duty was sent down
here to Lausanne on a permanent
assignment. Naturally, I am
quite happy to be in French
Switzerland, and I have found
some very charming people here.
My desk is in the office of the
vice-consul, Mr. Fletcher Dexter,
an old resident of Lausanne, familiarly known here as "le maire
d'Ouchy." Mr. Dexter is one of
the finest chaps I have ever met,
and knows everybody in the city,
from Greek ex-royalty to the chief
of police. And we have some
great specimens here, black-andtans from all over Europe, living
at expensive hotels and forgetting
to pay their bills! Constantine
has just left for St. Moritz, but at
my hotel there are Turkish
princes galore, Bulgarians, half:
starved boches, Greeks and a few
rotten Americans. Our good patriot, Romand Rolland is living
just a ways down the lake, and
there are plenty more like him
about. The Swiss themselves
are charming people, and I have
met a number of army officers who
are very nice to me. Captain Gautier, of the General Staff, is one
of my best friends here, and a
young artillery officer comes regularly to tea with me to smoke
American cigarettes and borrow
copies of Life both of which please
him immensely.
The other evening he became enthusiastic over a
pair of infantry trench boots he
saw in my apartment, and I
traded them with him for a pair
of black patent leather riding
boots. Wait until you see me
with them on!
I spent a wonderful week in
Paris at the time the city was
wild with excitement over the armistice and royalty was arriving
every day. I caught a glimpse of
King George and his sons, and
paid five francs for standing room
in a push cart along the Champs
Elyees to see the Belgian king
and queen. They were accorded a
marvelous reception, naturally,
and the broad avenue, lined with
boche cannon and tanks and remnants of Zepps, with an outer lining of the choicest, picked troops
—all veterans of the Marne, the
Yser and Verdun—was a sight to
behold on that afternoon. The city
was literally full of Americans,

Gives Detailed Account of Attack on
the Huns in which He was
Wounded.

Capt. W. H. King, D. S. 0., of
the Canadian Army, spoke at the
Thursday Open Forum, giving a
vivid account of a raid in which
he took part in the latter part of
1917, at Hill No. 70, near Lens.
He illustrated with a diagram of
the trenches raided, the three
parts being called Nun's Alley, Nabob Alley and Cinnabar. After
rehearsing the raid behind the
lines in trenches marked out with
tape, the three companies came
up to the attacking trench at 10.30
in the evening, making ready to attack at 12.30.
The night was clear, with a
full moon. The party advanced,
crawling through the barbed wire
entanglements and falling into
shell holes half filled with water.
The Germans kept the skies lit up
with flare shells. The barrage of
the artillery in the rear sometimes fell short. The companies
searched some houses in a village
and found them empty, erected
barricades in the enemy trenches,
and worked back and forth in the
latter, bombing out dug-outs and
taking prisoners and machine
guns.
At 1 o'clock the signal was
given to return, all except supporting machine gun parties to
cover the retirement. After ten
minutes these also returned. Besides the destruction of the enemy trenches, capturing of prisoners and machine guns, the raid resulted in the acquirement of a lot
of valuable information, a great
increase in the morale of the Canadian troops and a corresponding
lowering of that of the boche.
In was in this engagement that
Captain King was slightly wounded. In his lecture he described the
treatment in the first-aid posts,
dressing stations, casualty clearing stations and the base hospitals.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in publishing the following letter
from Lieut. Walter S. Hastings,
former instructor in French at
the University. He is now with
the American Legation at Berne,
holding the office of assistant to
the Olitary attache.
Lausanne, Switzerland,
January 12.
My Dear Dr. Brush—I have
been in Switzerland for over a
month now, and after reporting to
Berne for duty was sent down
here to Lausanne on a permanent
assignment. Naturally, I am
quite happy to be in French
Switzerland, and I have found
some very charming people here.
My desk is in the office of the
vice-consul, Mr. Fletcher Dexter,
an old resident of Lausanne, familiarly known here as "le maire
d'Ouchy." Mr. Dexter is one of
the finest chaps I have ever met,
and knows everybody in the city,
from Greek ex-royalty to the chief
of police. And we have some
great specimens here, black-andtans from all over Europe, living
at expensive hotels and forgetting
to pay their bills! Constantine
has just left for St. Moritz, but at
my hotel there are Turkish
princes galore, Bulgarians, half:
starved boches, Greeks and a few
rotten Americans. Our good patriot, Romand Rolland is living
just a ways down the lake, and
there are plenty more like him
about. The Swiss themselves
are charming people, and I have
met a number of army officers who
are very nice to me. Captain Gautier, of the General Staff, is one
of my best friends here, and a
young artillery officer comes regularly to tea with me to smoke
American cigarettes and borrow
copies of Life both of which please
him immensely.
The other evening he became enthusiastic over a
pair of infantry trench boots he
saw in my apartment, and I
traded them with him for a pair
of black patent leather riding
boots. Wait until you see me
with them on!
I spent a wonderful week in
Paris at the time the city was
wild with excitement over the armistice and royalty was arriving
every day. I caught a glimpse of
King George and his sons, and
paid five francs for standing room
in a push cart along the Champs
Elyees to see the Belgian king
and queen. They were accorded a
marvelous reception, naturally,
and the broad avenue, lined with
boche cannon and tanks and remnants of Zepps, with an outer lining of the choicest, picked troops
—all veterans of the Marne, the
Yser and Verdun—was a sight to
behold on that afternoon. The city
was literally full of Americans,
both officers and men and I was
amazed at the remarkable way in
